climbs.name: Punked Out Porpoise
climbs.fa: Craig Fry, Dave Evans, Jim Angione, 11/1979

content.description:
Great JT adventure climbing on an obvious line leads to a very nice summit.  A handful of 5.8 moves at the start are followed by engaging jug hauling.

A thoughtless person could probably tear most of the holds/route off and leave it all at the base so be careful!

Start at a left slanting thin crack behind a boulder, hand traverse left on jugs to huge hollow plates end on a large ledge and gear belay using 2" cams or sling plates (5.8+ ~70 feet).

Above follow giant steep holds up to a fine thin hands crack leading to the summit and gear belay with 2-3" cams (5.7+ ~70 feet).

Enjoy the view.
content.protection: Standard JT rack to 2" with one 3" cam for the last belay.  Small cams for the crux and traverse.  There are no fixed anchors on this route, please don't add any.
content.location:
Southwest face of Punk Rock is this obvious line we have all looked up at while heading to Mental Physics.

An arduous boulder scrambling approach directly from the main trail below the rock leads to the climb's start.

Descent is a short exposed 4th class off the northeast corner of the summit block.  Fun 3rd class scrambling northwest toward Lenticular Dome will lead you back to the route's start.

content.description:
This climb has been toproped, but not led. Climb the face 40 feet right of the first pitch of Punked Out Porpoise.

Face climb up to the base of a short, vertical thin crack. Move right (10a) over to the arete, then move back left to the top of the thin crack. Face climb straight up steep, plated patina (10b), ending at the big ledge level with the first pitch belay of Punked Out Porpoise.
content.protection: Can be toproped off a natural horn anchor, but you'll need lots of webbing and/or a short length of rigging rope to leave a rap anchor.
content.location: This toprope climb is best accessed by climbing the first pitch of Punked Out Porpoise, then moving right about 40 feet on the big ledge.

content.description: With large sweeping walls around, this climb makes you feel like you are in the mountains.  Runout flakes and a wide chimney lead 30 feet up to the start of the serious climbing.  A 5.10A sequence on somewhat loose holds leads to crux thin hands jamming.  A flared, overhanging chimney above (5.10A or B) is the best part of the climb.
content.location: This is an obvious left-curving chimney, high on the east face.
